title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: import module can easily load data MeTEor. Just press button ‘Click data importing’.  Example data can easily selected via Environment > Select data.frame > “covid_data” “example_data”. external file can load data.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: covid_data loaded MeTEor. Configurator can select subset data analysis. can select timepoint categorical variable levels metabolites

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: principal component analysis performed selected time point. eigenvalues principal components shown diagram upper left corner. scatter plot observations colored selected grouping variable displayed upper right corner. contributions variables principal components biplot displayed bottom. 3D scatterplot can also created bottom panel. principal components can selected dropdown menu different dimensions.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: TCAM unsupervised tensor factorization method analysis multiway data longitudinal omics data.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: can perform binary classification using three different algorithms: logistic regression (LR), random forest (RF), XGBoost (XGB). Multiple sizes test set type cross-validation used, either stratified 5-fold cross-validation leave-one-cross-validation (LOOCV). instances test set size set 0%, application compute ROC curve. section provides metabolite selection feature allows load ten important features. number can less features used model.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: Repeated measures ANOVA can used feature selection analyzing different features impact outcome variable across multiple measurements conditions within subjects. helps identify significant features considering within-subject correlations dependencies, aiding selection relevant predictors outcome variable.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: section presents ridge plots contrasting distribution selected metabolites (see: Select Metabolites:) different measurement time points. measurement times compared can selected menu box.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: Line plots visualize mean metabolite course category group. x-axis time points, metabolite. lines colored selected category.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: Cluster Heatmap tool allows visualize cluster metabolite data across different time points multiple metabolites. tool generates heatmap plot row represents single observation, column represents metabolites selected timepoint. plot can customized changing number clusters rows columns downloaded PNG image right-clicking .

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: enrichment analysis allows users perform database queries selected metabolites.

title: MeTEor Tutorial
text: Disclaimer: API MetaboAnalyst currently available, therefore developed workaround. top table displays names selected metabolites. field step 1, names metabolites shown.  initiate analysis, users can edit copy names selected metabolites head MetaboAnalyst ID conversion. IDs needed map metabolites known KEGG pathways.  Paste metabolites provided form click ‘Submit’ perform metabolite ID conversion.  mapping selected metabolites. Click bottom, show data csv.  Copy data head back MeTEor.  Paste content field step 2.  Click ‘Get enriched pathways’ receive list pathways selected metabolites present, ranked occurrence.  pathway includes outlinks interactive KEGG pathways metabolites highlighted red, enabling deeper analysis functional understanding measured metabolites. Users can click highlighted metabolites analysis.

title: MeTEor Preprocessing steps
text: first step load unprocessed data set “raw_example_data”. data set represents sample metabolomic data exhibits common issues missing values duplicates. Additionally, current format adhere specifications required MeTEor.
code: # read in CSV file data("raw_example_data") head(raw_example_data[, 1:8], n = 5) #> # A tibble: 5 × 8 #>      id treatment   sex  comp metabolite_1 metabolite_2  time metabolite_3 #>   <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1     1         0     0     1        1.88         0.750     1       -2.23  #> 2     1         0     0     1        2.22        -0.167     2       -1.05  #> 3     1         0     0     1        1.85         0.221     3       -0.681 #> 4     1         0     0     1        0.339        1.94      4       -2.36  #> 5     1         0     0     1        1.16         1.20      5       -2.54

title: MeTEor Preprocessing steps
text: first step check whether duplicate cases contained data record. case, can removed data set.
code: # check if the data contains duplicates duplicated_rows <- raw_example_data[duplicated(raw_example_data), ]  # drop duplicates raw_example_data <- raw_example_data[!duplicated(raw_example_data), ]  head(raw_example_data[, 1:8], n = 5) #> # A tibble: 5 × 8 #>      id treatment   sex  comp metabolite_1 metabolite_2  time metabolite_3 #>   <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1     1         0     0     1        1.88         0.750     1       -2.23  #> 2     1         0     0     1        2.22        -0.167     2       -1.05  #> 3     1         0     0     1        1.85         0.221     3       -0.681 #> 4     1         0     0     1        0.339        1.94      4       -2.36  #> 5     1         0     0     1        1.16         1.20      5       -2.54

title: MeTEor Preprocessing steps
text: data set contains columns irrelevant analysis, can removed data set.
code: # reorder columns raw_example_data <- raw_example_data %>% relocate("time", .before = "metabolite_1")  # drop column measurement_complete since it is not used raw_example_data <- raw_example_data %>% select(-comp)  head(raw_example_data[, 1:8], n = 5) #> # A tibble: 5 × 8 #>      id treatment   sex  time metabolite_1 metabolite_2 metabolite_3 #>   <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1     1         0     0     1        1.88         0.750       -2.23  #> 2     1         0     0     2        2.22        -0.167       -1.05  #> 3     1         0     0     3        1.85         0.221       -0.681 #> 4     1         0     0     4        0.339        1.94        -2.36  #> 5     1         0     0     5        1.16         1.20        -2.54  #> # ℹ 1 more variable: metabolite_4 <dbl>

title: MeTEor Preprocessing steps
text: analysis MeTEor, important metabolite values variables “numeric” type. “time” variable also variable type “numeric” “integer”. categorical variables can different data types.
code: # check if all data is numeric non_numeric_columns <- names(raw_example_data)[!sapply(raw_example_data, is.numeric)]  # transform to numeric cleaned_data <- raw_example_data %>% mutate_if(is.character, as.numeric)  # Select the numeric columns you want to normalize columns_to_normalize <- 5:ncol(cleaned_data)  # Normalize the selected numeric columns normalize <- function(x) {   (x - min(x)) / (max(x) - min(x)) }  cleaned_data[, columns_to_normalize] <- apply(cleaned_data[, columns_to_normalize], 2, normalize)  head(cleaned_data[, 1:8], n = 5) #> # A tibble: 5 × 8 #>      id treatment   sex  time metabolite_1 metabolite_2 metabolite_3 #>   <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1     1         0     0     1           NA           NA        0.217 #> 2     1         0     0     2           NA           NA        0.392 #> 3     1         0     0     3           NA           NA        0.447 #> 4     1         0     0     4           NA           NA        0.199 #> 5     1         0     0     5           NA           NA        0.172 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: metabolite_4 <dbl>

title: MeTEor Preprocessing steps
text: dataset contains missing values, need addressed conducting analysis MeTEor. Initially, ’s crucial identify metabolites missing data. metabolites may exhibit higher prevalence missing values. instance, metabolites 10% missing values can filtered initially. Subsequently, remaining missing values, techniques like k-nearest neighbor imputation can employed impute missing data.
code: # Find columns with missing values columns_with_missing <- names(cleaned_data)[colSums(is.na(cleaned_data)) > 0] head(columns_with_missing) #> [1] "metabolite_1"  "metabolite_2"  "metabolite_5"  "metabolite_8"  #> [5] "metabolite_35" "metabolite_36" # Remove columns with more than 10% NA cleaned_data <- cleaned_data[, which(colMeans(!is.na(cleaned_data)) > 0.9)]  # impute columns using KNN data_meta_imputed <- kNN(cleaned_data, numFun = weightedMean, weightDist=TRUE, imp_var = FALSE) #> Warning in kNN(cleaned_data, numFun = weightedMean, weightDist = TRUE, imp_var #> = FALSE): Nothing to impute, because no NA are present (also after using #> makeNA) head(data_meta_imputed[, 1:8], n = 5) #>   id treatment sex time metabolite_3 metabolite_4 metabolite_6 metabolite_7 #> 1  1         0   0    1    0.2173387    0.5713050    0.4797063    0.7120786 #> 2  1         0   0    2    0.3923829    0.5010947    0.5095061    0.8321946 #> 3  1         0   0    3    0.4468586    0.5865550    0.4192313    0.3186937 #> 4  1         0   0    4    0.1986379    0.5804491    0.5659878    0.6971688 #> 5  1         0   0    5    0.1716386    0.6713395    0.3987762    0.7795458

title: MeTEor Preprocessing steps
text: data format transformed wide long format make compatible MeTEor. also involves reorganizing columns ensure dataset structured appropriately.
code: data_meta_imputed_long <- data_meta_imputed  %>%                               pivot_longer(!c("id", "time", "sex", "treatment"),                                             names_to = "metabolites", values_to = "values") %>%                               relocate(time, .after = id) %>%                               relocate(sex, .after = values) %>%                               relocate(treatment, .after = values)  head(data_meta_imputed_long, n = 5) #> # A tibble: 5 × 6 #>      id  time metabolites  values treatment   sex #>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>         <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1     1 metabolite_3  0.217         0     0 #> 2     1     1 metabolite_4  0.571         0     0 #> 3     1     1 metabolite_6  0.480         0     0 #> 4     1     1 metabolite_7  0.712         0     0 #> 5     1     1 metabolite_9  0.402         0     0

title: Authors and Citation
text: Grabert Gordon. Author, maintainer. Dehncke Daniel. Author. Tushar. Author. List Markus. Author. Kraft Anke RM. Author. Cornberg Markus. Author. Hiller Karsten. Author. Kacprowski Tim. Author. . Funder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gordon G, Daniel D, Tushar M, Markus L, Anke RM K, Markus C, Karsten H, Tim K (2024). MeTEor: MeTEor - R Shiny app Metabolite Trajectory Exploration. R package version 1.0.0, https://github.com/scibiome/meteor, https://scibiome.github.io/meteor/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {MeTEor: MeTEor - an R Shiny app for Metabolite Trajectory Exploration},   author = {Grabert Gordon and Dehncke Daniel and More Tushar and List Markus and Kraft {Anke RM} and Cornberg Markus and Hiller Karsten and Kacprowski Tim},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.0, https://github.com/scibiome/meteor},   url = {https://scibiome.github.io/meteor/}, }

title: MeTEor - MEtabolite Trajectory ExplORer
text: `MeTEor` R Shiny application offers possibility explore longitudinal metabolomics data. purpose, variety statistical analysis visualization methods implemented MeTEor help user get quick overview data. Currently implemented features include: Dimensionality Reduction: PCA, Modern Tensor Factorization (TCAM) Statistical models: Linear Mixed Models, Repeated Measures ANOVA, Mixed ANOVA, Friedman test Prediction models: Logistic regression, Random Forest, XGBoost Network plots: Pearson correlation network, Gaussian graphical model Ridge plots Line plots Cluster heatmaps Volcano plots Enrichment: Map compounds (MetaboAnalyst ID Conversion), Map KEGG Pathways (KEGGREST)

title: MeTEor - MEtabolite Trajectory ExplORer
text: recommended option using MeTEor MeTEor Docker container, available Docker Hub. use , make sure Docker installed. Docker installation please check: https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/

title: MeTEor - MEtabolite Trajectory ExplORer
text: MeTEor also available R package. correct installation setup Miniconda environment necessary. installation `rminiconda` package described MacOS, Linux Windows.

title: MeTEor - MEtabolite Trajectory ExplORer
text: Please create empty folder ‘miniconda_py_r’ drive C./ . reason MeTEor installation Python necessary. make sure everything can installed correctly Miniconda environment created. problem can arise directory Miniconda installed contains spaces. workaround installation drive C./.
code: if (!requireNamespace("remotes", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("remotes") }  remotes::install_github("hafen/rminiconda")  rminiconda::install_miniconda(path = "C:\\miniconda_py_r", name='miniconda_for_meteor')

what: Real world metabolomics data set to test MeTEor — covid_data
